title: Regulating Government AI and the Challenge of Sociotechnical Design
research_description: This article reviews the complexities of regulating AI in government, particularly in the design and deployment of AI systems used to distribute public benefits, enforce regulations, and administer sanctions. It discusses the promise and peril of AI in governance, exploring the tension between innovation and accountability in AI-based decision-making systems.
research_results: The article presents a synthesis of the debate on government AI, focusing on the need for regulatory frameworks that can balance innovation with meaningful accountability. It identifies significant gaps in current regulatory approaches, emphasizing the importance of integrating organizational theory and legal constraints.
future_research: Future research should investigate best practices for internal governance of AI systems within public agencies and explore how external legal constraints can be adapted to better regulate AI's integration into public administration.
